newsitem.title: SOUTH AFRICA: Namibia says ivory revenues will go to conservation.
newsitem.headline: Namibia says ivory revenues will go to conservation.

text.p: Namibia, one of several southern African countries calling for the lifting of an ivory ban, says it will use money from the sale of its ivory stockpiles for elephant conservation and community development.
Malan Lindeque of Namibia's environment tourism ministy said the money from the sale of ivory would boost elephant conservation coffers.

"We have renewed the incentives for any personal profit from this trade. All revenues from this ivory trade is going back into elephant conservation and to community development," he told South Africa's state television.
He said Namibia's ivory stocks, around 40 tonnes, had been registered and inspected.
